subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ...  This doesn t seem much different from Spanish speakers learning which words use |y| and which use |ll| or which use |z| and which use |s|.
messageBody:
John Cowan skribis:
>
> Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:
>>
>> I pronounce "ah" and "awe" exactly the same.
>> It's exactly the same sound I use for the first
>> vowel in "nautical". For me, any distinction
>> between QS letters #32, #33 and #34 is difficult
>> to even imagine. This has been a stumbling block
>> for me in trying to learn QS. I don't have a good
>> way to guess which of these letters would be
>> most appropriate to use for sounds that I cannot
>> distinguish.
>
> It's a problem, yes. On one theory, you need to
> learn which is conventionally used for which, as
> in the traditional orthography;
<...snip...>

This doesn't seem much different from Spanish
speakers learning which words use |y| and which
use |ll| or which use |z| and which use |s|. These
pairs are pronounced differently in some dialects,
but are merged in others.

--Ph. D.
